description: a(n) = number of integer strings s(0),...,s(n) counted by array T in A026374 that have s(n)=4; also a(n)=T(2n,n-2).
comments: Number of lattice paths from (0,0) to (2n,4), using steps U=(1,1), D=(1,-1) and at even levels(zero, positive and negative) also H=(2,0). Example: a(3)=9 because we have UUUUUD, UUUUDU, UUUDUU, UUDUUU, UDUUUU, DUUUUU, HUUUU, UUHUU and UUUUH. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jan 30 2004
formula: a(n)=[t^(n+2)](1+3t+t^2)^n. a(n)=sum(3^(2j-n-2)*binomial(n, j)*binomial(j, n+2-j), j=ceil((n+2)/2)..n). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jan 30 2004E.g.f. : exp(3x)BesselI(2, 2x); a(n)=sum{k=0..n, binomial(n, k)binomial(2k, k+2)}. - _Paul Barry_, Sep 20 2004Conjecture: n*(n+4)*a(n) -3*(n+2)*(2*n+3)*a(n-1) +5*(n+2)*(n+1)*a(n-2)=0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 24 2012G.f.: (3*x-1+(1-6*x+7*x^2)/sqrt(5*x^2-6*x+1))/(2*x^2). - _Mark van Hoeij_, Apr 18 2013a(n) ~ 5^(n+1/2)/(2*sqrt(Pi*n)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 07 2013Assuming offset 0: a(n) = C(2*n+4,n)*hypergeom([-n,-n-4],[-3/2-n],-1/4). - _Peter Luschny_, May 09 2016
author: _Clark Kimberling_
